QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. In your speech to a higher education conference on 23 September entitled `The quest for truth', you said that when parties to a debate compete for the exposure of their point of view `this political scenario often means the truth, the facts and the figures are lost' and `the headline, the grab and the spin take over from rational and informed debate'. You later added, `The distortion of information carried to the voters distorts and damages the democratic process.' On the same day you attended a Senate estimates committee and raised the Wright family as an issue by answering a Dorothy Dixer from Senator Ferris. Have you not contradicted your own words? In failing to accept Mr Hollway's advice to immediately correct the record, have you not carried distorted information to the voters and damaged the democratic process? Aren't you guilty of the most blatant double standards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Evans for that question. Senator Evans, you are, I think, quoting pretty well exactly correctly from the speech I made. I would not walk away from that speech for one minute. If I had an opportunity to make it again and again and again, I would continue to do so. You then lead in to the question of the so-called Wright family. Again, as has happened before—Madam President, I did indicate that I would point it out to you every time it happens—an inference against a minister is contained in a question. You say `by answering a Dorothy Dixer from Senator Ferris', yet I think I have in this place or in other places indicated on plenty of occasions, or at least one or two, that there was no arrangement for Senator Ferris to ask any particular question whatsoever.

ANSWER.PARA: If, Senator Evans, you want to set the precedent in this place that when you ask a senator something and they stand up and give you the answer, you consistently, having been given that answer, allege that that answer is untrue, that is up to you. But I think you are going down a very unfortunate road. You have asked this question in previous sitting weeks and you have been given the answer, and I stand by that answer.

The second part of your question goes to immediately following up and I answered that question last time, too. I gave you all the material you could possibly want and indicated in the answer when I gave that material that what I wanted to do was ensure that the material I gave was correct. I in fact said last time in this place that I clearly did not leave time enough because, as late as 6 o'clock the night before I gave all that information in the chamber, further information arrived from the department.

So let us not pretend that between when Mr Hollway advised me that the Wright family was in fact not an actual family in itself, although it started off as an actual family, and when I signed the letter nothing was happening. Advice was sought from the clerk. The letter was changed to make sure that it was distributed. I have seen some press coverage since I have been away that I secretly wrote to the estimates committee. The estimates committee is the appropriate place to write.

Do you know what the amendment was that was made at the suggestion of the clerk? It was put at the bottom of the letter to ask the chairman to distribute it to Labor members. If that is trying to keep something secret—heavens above! What else would you do other than advise Labor's members of the committee? Senators are not only entitled but obligated to try and ensure that they have got the information correct. I did that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the minister that this question is about voracity of information given to the Senate. That is the very point of the question. Minister, did you not say in the same speech on 23 September that it would be unwise to blame the media at large in public debates because `the media frequently face enormous difficulty in ascertaining the facts'. Would you agree that their job is made even more difficult when ministers of the crown allow distortions and misrepresentations to take root in the public mind by not moving to correct the facts at the earliest opportunity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I do agree that the media sometimes have a very difficult task to get the correct information and to get the facts. But let us understand one thing in this matter: the so-called Wright family was based on an actual family. That turns out not to mean that it was an actual family because children were added, et cetera. I think the first of the actual families tabled vis-a-vis being cut out of Austudy by the means test was the basis for the Wright family. They would have, other than the actual means test, got Austudy.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us not pretend for one minute that those families would be able to access welfare benefits. If you are walking away from that, if you think people in million dollar houses should be able to, then that is up to you to raise. You are asking me whether the impression created in the media was wrong. If the impression in the media is that some people were incorrectly getting Austudy, then no—the impression in the media is not wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. What message does the overwhelming endorsement of the Liberal member Jackie Kelly in the Lindsay by-election say about the Howard government's policies? What does Jackie Kelly's re-election reveal about the attitude of Lindsay voters towards the opposition's obstruction of the 1996-97 budget? Is this a further justification of the confidence in the coalition government that the voters of Lindsay gave on 2 March and reaffirmed seven months later on 19 October?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —This was the one I was hoping to get from the Labor Party, but not today. It is a great victory and a great credit to Jackie Kelly, too. There is within the results some very serious messages, I believe, for the Labor Party and minority parties in this place. What it did was reaffirm that voters, who threw Labor out in unprecedented numbers in March, wish that the program they sought to be enacted actually does get enacted. There is no doubt about that at all.

ANSWER.PARA: Labor tried to scare in that campaign. Labor tried to scare on the basis of the last budget—a budget which you will remember was written up as a fair go budget. But, again, rather than listen, Labor went back and said, `This is the by-election in which you the voters can send a message to the coalition government to hold back.' The interesting thing is that the voters said, `No, we want change. We are tired of Labor. We had it for 13 years. We had record unemployment, record high interest rates, record debt. We voted for change and we expect that change to be endorsed and supported.' That is the key message that came out of the Lindsay by-election and it is a message that ought to be listened to in this place.
I will quote a couple of newspaper reports. I don't do it often, but I think they are spot on. The Daily Telegraph stated:

The win is rightly seen as an endorsement of government policies and a sharp reminder to other policies that its reform program cannot be impeded without angering voters. Mr Howard is justified in claiming the endorsement of last March has been renewed while Labor leader Kim Beazley must accept that the voters do not want obstruction of the general government program. Voters do indeed want to give Mr Howard a fair go in introducing changes that will produce fundamental improvements to employment, productivity and efficiency.
That is exactly what we were elected to do, exactly what we want to do. The message in it to Labor is to not obstruct in this place—

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—Senator Cook again says, `Rubbish!' Still he will not listen to the wishes of the people. The people voted for change. They want to see the new program implemented. They want to see the new government given a fair go, in the same way, Senator Cook, they wanted to see Jackie Kelly given a fair go. Will you listen? All he says is, `Rubbish!' He will not listen to the people. The West Australian stated:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Howard can rightly claim that it reinforces his mandate to implement the key policies on which he and his colleagues were elected—the part sale of Telstra and subsequent financial commitments to the environment, the reformation of the nation's industrial relations law and the implementation of budget measures.
There can be no doubt at all, as these newspapers have objectively reported, that by their vote at the beginning of March the people have endorsed a program that they wish to have effect.

The message is there for Labor. Since 1993 in the seat of Lindsay, Labor's primary vote has dropped 20 per cent from the March election and now this by-election. Their primary vote has crashed, but they still will not listen to the people. There is an opportunity for Labor to say, `The people have spoken clearly in March. The people have re-endorsed their position in this by-election. We will give the new government an opportunity. We will be prepared to allow its budget through. We will be prepared to allow its funding base for the Natural Heritage Trust—$1 billion to be spent on the environment—'(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, why did you state on Meet the Press on 25 August that `Labor knew before the election that its target of five per cent by the year 2000 was unachievable' and that Labor had been told that when your department had already advised you that this was not correct? Why did you repeat this in the Senate in answer to a question without notice on 10 September? Haven't you, yet again, as in the case of the Wright family, misled both the parliament and the Australian people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you Senator Bolkus for that question because it does give me an opportunity to reiterate for members opposite how many times they were told that their targets were askew and unlikely to be achieved. It is wondrous how many times they were privately told.
—Are you trying to say you are right now?

—Senator Bolkus, your job is to ask the question; my job is to answer it, okay?— how many times they were told that they were not on track and they were not going to get there. In September 1994 Mr Ted Evans, the secretary to the Treasury, is reported to have said that `it will be extraordinarily difficult to achieve the government's target of five per cent unemployment by the turn of the century'. He went as far as describing that as `very ambitious', which are strong words indeed for the secretary to the Treasury.

ANSWER.PARA: In the same month—this is in 1994, so there was plenty of time for this message to sink in—Dr Vince FitzGerald, who headed the Keating government's national inquiry into savings, expressed concern that our national savings rate would not be sufficient to bring unemployment down to an acceptable level—five per cent or below—within the remainder of the present decade. You would have thought over 12 months or so that message would have sunk in. Dr John Quiggin, the professor of economics at James Cook University, described by one newspaper as `a strident supporter of Working Nation', said in June 1995 that the government had failed to allow for discouraged workers in its forecasts and therefore unemployment would still be running at eight per cent in the year 2000.

It is quite obvious that, if key advisers and commentators were speaking in these terms and were in fact saying that you could not get there, how could the government itself have been blind to these realities? Of course they were not. Labor knew, as well as I did and its advisers did, that, in the absence of appropriate macro‐economic and micro‐economic policies, the achievement of its much touted five per cent target was no more than a mere fantasy.

Senator Bolkus asks me as to some advice from the department, and I suspect that he is not actually talking about advice. I think he is talking about one portion of an incoming government brief, which the senator opposite, I think, seeks to say or assert, concludes that the department offers advice to the incoming government that five per cent was achievable, and that is not the case, if that is what you are asserting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. You know what I was asserting and you also know that you have not even tried to answer the question in that respect. Isn't it true, Minister, that your bumbling and inept performance, as we have seen again today, as minister for employment has forced the Prime Minister to set up a cabinet employment committee to do the job that you are paid for and to do the job that you have comprehensively failed to perform?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, even I in my darkest moments in assessing your capacity did not think you would be silly enough to ask that sort of question. You, having been a minister for so long, should understand that the creation of real jobs is an across government problem and responsibility. You know that as well as I do.
—What are you responsible for?

—Senator Bolkus inquires what am I responsible for, indicating that he does not seem to know what the employment portfolio is all about. After so many years in government, perhaps not in cabinet—I cannot even remember where he was—he does not understand that the employment portfolio is responsible largely for two aspects relating to employment: one is labour market programs, training and getting people job ready; and the other is employment services which match people with those jobs that are available. I welcome the opportunity to highlight the fact that the actual creation of real jobs is an across government responsibility, something that is clearly misunderstood by Senator Bolkus.(Time expired)

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Last week several financial institutions cut their mortgage interest rates, which is very welcome, of course. I ask the Minister to inform the Senate how much Australians will benefit from these cuts and how does the government's budget further improve living standards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for this important question which is of interest to virtually all Australians. There is no doubt that the big reductions in home mortgage rates by half a percentage point or more announced on Friday is very good news for most Australian families. The cuts announced by Westpac, St George, FAI and Aussie Home Loans means that all these substantial lenders now offer home loan rates below eight per cent. This is the first time in two decades that variable home loan rates have been this low. Not since the mid‐1970s have families been able to enjoy such low interest rates in paying off their most valuable asset—their homes.

ANSWER.PARA: The latest cut, for example, by Aussie Home Loans provides a benefit of roughly $45 a month or over $500 a year for a family with a $100,000 25‐year mortgage. Westpac, as many senators will know, also substantially cut its first option variable rate on Friday and announced that this provides a benefit of around $10,000 to customers over the life of their loan.

In fact, since the election, variable home mortgage rates offered by the four big banks have fallen by about 1¼ percentage points and the rates now offered by Aussie Home Loans and others are even lower. I say to Senator Cook, who is trying to interject, that the interest rates, as I said, are great news for Australian families. The Treasurer Peter Costello said on Friday, `This is a low inflation economy with interest rates falling and this will be a great relief for those Australians who are looking for loans and paying off mortgages.'

Last week figures were released that showed that underlying inflation for the year to September was 2.4 per cent—well within our target of two to three per cent on average over the economic cycle. Figures also showed a moderation in wage presses, with average weekly ordinary time earnings rising just 0.7 per cent for the quarter.

Let there be no mistake: these cuts are possible because of the decisive action this government took in the budget to rein in the deficit. By reining in the deficit, we have taken the pressure off interest rates. We have already seen one cut in official interest rates and significant cuts in mortgage and business rates. This is in stark contrast to what happened under the Labor government. Over the last 2½ years under Labor—

TALK.START.PARA: —Try the last six months.
—the only way interest rates went, by and large, was up, Senator Sherry.
—That is not true. That is not true.

—Up, up, up! Labor, Senator Sherry, as you know—we can demonstrate this quite easily, Senator Sherry—is the high interest rate party. This government wants to get interest rates down, and we have already shown that this is possible.

—I ask the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs: what measures did you or your office take to correct the record after your department advised you that you had incorrectly inferred in the Australian of 19 August that the department had advised the former Labor government that the five per cent unemploy ment rate was unachievable? Did the department provide you with a draft press release or letter to the editor of the Australian to correct this misleading statement in the same way as they provided a press release to correct the record on the bogus Wright family on 26 September, a day after the story appeared in the Daily Telegraph ? Will you table the department's advice, as you did in the case of the Wright family?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for that question. It contains an incorrect assertion on your part. I am just trying to find the Australian article of the 19th—I have found it. I assume that that is what you are relying on; it is headed `Regional jobless may top 10pc, Crean warns'. You might help me by indicating whether or not that is the article you are relying on. Is that right?
—Yes.
—That article, written by David McKenzie, says:

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Vanstone said that at the time of the March election, her department had advised Mr Crean, the then employment minister, that unemployment by the year 2000 would have been, at best, 6.8 per cent.

This is perhaps an example of how careful journalists have to be when they paraphrase press releases. The wording in the press release of 18 August—which the article of the 19th is responding to, and which I presume is what occasioned Mr Crean to speak out as well—is this:
DEETYA has advised that at the time of the election, on the information available to the previous government, unemployment in 2000 would have been between 6.8 and 7.3 per cent.

This matter has been dealt with by Dr Kemp in the other place, and the situation is this: questions were asked, obviously by us, as to what employment scenarios were around. Those questions were asked not long after the last election and were based, in part, on the Treasurer's statement of 12 March, I think.

Had your government not been so gutless, had it been prepared to ask those questions, that information would have been available to it as well. The fact that you did not choose to ask is probably the same reason you did not choose to release all the Treasury papers when we asked you to. The comment that I have made is that at the time of the election that information was available. You had a whole department to get it from. If you did not choose to ask the question, then, with respect, I suggest that that is your problem.

Can I give you another hint, Senator, as to why you probably did not ask? Let me give you a few more names of people who were telling you that you were not on track. Helen Hughes, in September 1995, said:
The unemployment rate not 8.2 per cent would be no better than seven per cent by the year 2000 if present growth levels were maintained.
Then John Quiggin, on 1 September 1995, said:
There is no doubt, the government cannot possibly achieve five per cent under its current policies.
This is the great fan of Working Nation.
The target of Working Nation is not achievable with 3.7 per cent growth . . . then it is dishonest of the government to maintain that the five per cent rate is its target.
An Australian editorial said:
. . . Mr Crean claims we are on track to cut unemployment to 5 per cent. At best he is deluded and at worst Mr Crean is not telling the truth.
If you did not ask the department whether you could get there, I suggest the reason is that you knew the answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked a question in relation to what the department provided by way of draft press releases, and making assumptions, as I have had to because of the answer, I ask this: Minister, what do you understand is meant by the instruction in the Prime Minister's guide on the key elements of ministerial responsibility that a minister should be `honest in their public dealings'—
—Madam President, on the point of order: it seems to me that this is not a supplementary question but a different issue. I therefore raise this for your consideration.

—Madam President, on a point of order: I think that it would be a reasonable thing for you to hear all of Senator O'Brien's supplementary question before you rule on a point of order in relation to whether it is in order or not.
—I will listen to the remainder of the question.

—and that `any misconception caused inadvertently should be corrected at the earliest opportunity'? Why did you fail to follow these basic rules of ministerial behaviour after clear advice from your department's secretary?
—I think the supplementary is in order within the wide ranging way supplementary questions are being interpreted at the present time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are asking vis a vis the five per cent issue, I have had no suggestion from the department, to the best of my knowledge, that a press release should be put out. The department did draw to one of my staffer's attention the incorrect reporting.
—That is not you.

—It is the office; I make no doubt about it. The report in the Australian gave the impression that the department had so advised; that is true. But there was no suggestion that a press release was put out. Senator, if every time a reporter mis‐paraphrases a press release, if every time I had to correct something that one of your people on the front bench—or perhaps even you yourself—or every other journalist got wrong at the edge here, I would never do my job. I would spend my time correcting errors in the paper. This is not an error created by myself.
—Who got it wrong then—you or the journo?
—The journo.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, are you aware that the Prime Minister in his address to the National Press Club in February said:

QUESTION.PARA: I think it would be much better if we said to ministers: right you are the minister, you're running the department, you take the decisions but, you know, if you really make a hash of it, well it's a very competitive world out there and we can have a few changes.

Minister, is it not true that you have alienated your department because of your ill‐judged cover-ups with both the bogus Wright family and the five per cent unemployment rate target statement, you have alienated the jobless by slashing $1.8 billion out of job creation programs and you have abused parliamentary process on at least three occasions by misleading on the Wrights, on the Labor government's job targets and on the Democrats Internet messages? Do you think this could fairly be described as making a hash of it and it is time for you to go? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —If anybody made a hash of things recently, it was you people in the Lindsay by‐election. Without a shadow of a doubt, what a hash. No wonder you are looking a bit quiet over there, a little bit embarrassed. That was a punch badly thrown.

ANSWER.PARA: This question really does not deserve an answer but, since it has been asked, let me answer it. Senator Faulkner suggests that I have alienated my department. I do not think that is true at all. I have worked very closely with the department. The department have apologised for creating the impression that the Wright family was an actual family. They deeply regret that, and we have done everything we can—that is, I have and they have—to set the record straight.

As to the five per cent, there has been no misleading there. If you want me to repeat the number of occasions on which you people were told that you were not going to get there, I would be happy to do so if you would give me more time to do it in. So I think you are out of the ballpark here. You have not plugged in. You have fallen out of your own tree again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, my supplementary question to Senator Vanstone is this: in the Prime Minister's share scandal press conference on 16 October, he was asked whether you, Minister, should resign for misleading the Senate and he replied:

BREAK.PARA: I will have to have a look at all of that. I have not really looked at it, so I will.
Minister, has the Prime Minister interviewed you about this particular matter? What action was taken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has available to him all the information you have. I have not had a conversation with the Prime Minister about this. It was mentioned in passing at the end of a meeting about a range of other matters simply querying how this happened. I told him how it happened, and I will repeat what I said to you in here. I do not believe for one minute that anyone in the department intended to mislead me just as I did not intend to mislead the chamber. It was a case of a notation at the bottom saying `based on an actual family' and a number of people saying, `What does that mean?' and people saying, `It's an actual family.' That is all it was.

ANSWER.PARA: You can try to make something more out of it if you like, but I repeat here what I said last time: I do not believe—and the Prime Minister accepts my view—that anyone in the department intentionally misled me. Not for one minute do I believe that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Hill, the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. The Uruguay Round of GATT and formation of the World Trade Organisation was largely promoted in Australia as providing immense benefits to the economy. Magically, we would improve our balance of trade by greatly increasing our exports relative to our imports. Australia was supposed to come out $5.5 billion per annum to the good, and our agricultural sector was to be the main beneficiary and generator of wealth. Yet, on Four Corners last week, we saw a program that highlighted the change in investment regimes and ownership of various sectors of the beef export industry that has not brought benefits while our balance of trade has deteriorated. What have the actual trade and investment outcomes of the GATT agreement been in terms of both economic benefits and disbenefits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the senator in some way is trying to relate two unrelated matters. Our advice, and this is based on the former Industry Commission's assessment, is that the round will add about 1.1 per cent—that is, $3.7 billion—a year to Australia's income and $5 billion a year to Australia's exports when the commitments are fully implemented. We expect our balance of trade will improve as the domestic economy improves and Australian business can be more internationally competitive. That is why we are implementing a lot of these changes.
—You have slowed down the domestic economy.

—No, the big change is, if we can take pressure off public expenditure, we bring interest rates down, which is already occurring, and business can start to grow and be internationally competitive again. I remind the honourable senator also that 43 per cent of Australia's industrial exports will now face zero tariffs, an average cut to agricultural tariffs of 36 per cent was made—as agriculture was brought more fully under the multilateral rules and disciplines—and market access opportunities were opened and export subsidies cut.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the senator also that multilateral disciplines were extended to the services sector for the first time, protection was extended to intellectual property and the round provided for stronger rules, fairer dispute settlement and greater transparency. In other words, there is a whole series of benefits from which Australian industry and Australia will gain.

It is interesting to note also that, on top of that, industry has encouraged the government to develop an ambitious and forward looking agenda for further liberalisation to take to the first biennial conference of members of the World Trade Organisation, which will take place in Singapore in December this year. Far from being put off by what is occurring, industry is in fact challenging us to go forward and build upon the gains and the benefits of the Uruguay Round.

Even in relation to the beef industry to which the honourable senator refers, there have been advantages secured. There has been the removal of the US meat import law and its replacement with a much greater and more certain quota of 379,000 tonnes, affirmation of the commitment of the European Union not to subsidise beef into the Asia Pacific market and the complete liberalisation of the Korean beef market by the year 2001.

Certainly, there are temporary difficulties in relation to beef exports. There is no secret about that, but the future, on the basis of what has been gained to date, remains promising. An important point to remember is that, apart from the changes that we are implementing in terms of enabling Australian business to be more internationally competitive and taking pressure off its outgoings, investment itself remains a key to enhancing our competitiveness. In that regard foreign investment into the beef industry has played a fundamental role over the last decade in modernising the industry and developing better linkages with our customers overseas.

I urge the honourable senator to not be so pessimistic. The changes that have occurred have enabled a better outcome in the medium to longer term. The important thing now is to build upon them and to seize the opportunities that they present us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. It would seem that there are no updated figures since 1993. I would be very happy if the minister could provide the basis if there have been updated figures, because that indicates he is answering the same questions that I asked in 1993 with the same answers. All of the basic elements of the Four Corners story have actually been highlighted by the Greens in the past. The previous government ignored the fact that the aggressive political trade policy of economically powerful governments, coupled with a strong support for what they see as strategic industries, would ensure that the trade field is not level; the support of free investment and foreign ownership would lead to transfer pricing and other distortions; and increased foreign ownership by vertically integrated transnationals would result in unfair trade pressures on domestic producers. I ask: what is this government intending to do about this and where are the minister's updated figures?

—If there are updated figures, I will seek them, but I suspect that, it only being in the second year, it is very difficult to provide the sort of detail that the honourable senator wants. The point is that we actually want a trade field that is balanced in our favour. That is why the changes that we are implementing are resulting in lower interest rates and lowering inflation.
—Lower communication costs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Stott Despoja for the question. The World Bank study does not immediately come to mind and I was not at your committee meeting this morning, but I will have a look at the evidence that was presented and get back to you with a comment on that at a later time.

ANSWER.PARA: As to Dr Bruce Chapman's view that the proposed changes to HECS will skew the university population towards those who are the most wealthy in the community, it is not a view that I share. I do not say that that is a fact simply because it is Dr Chapman's view. It is worth noting, Senator Stott Despoja, that in the time when university education was free to students—that means that other people pay—the most disadvantaged people in the community got the least access.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cut it out.

—Senator Carr does not necessarily agree with me, but that is my view. When HECS was introduced, people said it would be the end of higher education. It clearly was not and the numbers have grown steadily ever since.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also my view that it is completely unfair to ask of a teacher, who has a low course cost and, relatively speaking, a lower income, the same contribution per annum that you ask of a doctor, who has a high course cost and a higher income afterwards. I think that is completely unfair.

In the policy we have put forward we have shifted the HECS arrangement from being a flat charge where everyone pays the same to more properly reflect both the cost of the course—that is, the benefit given by other taxpayers to that student in cash terms—and the private benefit that students receive from higher education, which is largely reflected by the income that they get. That is why we propose to keep nursing, for example, which is an expensive course, in the lower band. As you would well know, nurses do not achieve higher incomes for the rest of their lives.

To shift to a three-tiered HECS that purely reflected the cost of the course would, I believe, be inequitable. But one that has a blend of that—that acknowledges some have lower incomes and some have higher incomes—is a good thing. In summary, what we have done here is acknowledge that what Labor did when it introduced HECS was correct. We think it is correct that there is a public benefit in a well developed, higher education student and it is without question that there is a private benefit to the students who participate. The HECS contribution is an acknowledgment of that.

We are maintaining the excellent aspect of HECS—that you do not pay as you learn; you pay as you earn. We think that is a fairer system. Neville Wran, the former Labor Premier of New South Wales, suggested not charging everyone equally because everyone does not get an equal cost course and everyone does not get an equal private benefit. We are following his suggestion that it would be more equitable to shift to a three-tiered HECS. We think that is a much fairer way to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you, Minister. I did ask you whether you would stand by an earlier commitment you made to review those changes if the HECS hikes kept students from lower socioeconomic groups out of higher education. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), to a question without notice asked by Senator Faulkner today, relating to ministerial responsibility.

I think what we have in relation to Senator Vanstone is growing evidence of a pattern of behaviour from a minister which is totally unacceptable. We have a pattern of behaviour with a minister playing fast and loose with the truth. We have a pattern of deceit from Senator Vanstone. I think we have from this minister no understanding and no comprehension at all of the sorts of responsibilities that a minister has to tell the truth, both to the parliament and to the Australian people.

We now have clear evidence that Senator Vanstone has again misled this parliament. First, it was the `Wright family' exposed by the Labor Party in this place. Now we have exposed another very clear breach of Minister Vanstone's ministerial responsibilities. On 19 August in the Australian Senator Vanstone stated that at the time of the March election her department had advised Mr Crean, the then employment minister, that unemployment by the year 2000 would have been, at best, 6.8 per cent. The department has confirmed that after this statement was published in the Australian, the minister was informed by DEETYA that Mr Crean was advised about:
. . . a range of conditions that would need to be met to achieve the former government's 5 per cent unemployment rate target by the turn of the century.
The department says it did not put any view on the most likely outcome or suggest any particular level below which the unemployment rate was likely to fall.

When asked, this minister has categorically refused to make that departmental advice available to the Senate. Of course, when it was the case of the Wrights, Minister Vanstone was forced to make departmental advice available. I suggest, Minister, on this occasion, you will be forced to front up with the advice again. On 25 August, Minister Vanstone repeated her untruth on Channel 10's Meet the Press. She said:
Labor knew before the election that its target of five per cent by the year 2000 was unachievable; it had been told that. I know that's absolutely true.'
Then on 10 September in the Senate, Senator Vanstone repeated that untruth for a third time. In answer to a question from Senator Bolkus, she said:

BREAK.PARA: That is my understanding—that the Labor Party knew well that the target it was promoting as being achievable was not achievable . . . If you want to allege I am wrong, I am happy for you to do so, and I am happy to check the matter out.
When asked the supplementary question by Senator Bolkus:
Did you receive any other advice from your department to confirm your Meet the Press statement?
Senator Vanstone said:
I have nothing further to add.

During the estimates in October, the department detailed advice correcting the statement by the minister in her 19 August pronouncement in the Australian , after being pressured by the opposition. The First Assistant Secretary of the Economic and Policy Analysis Division of DEETYA, Mr Grant, said:

I have the Australian report in front of me. Certainly the statement which caused us to advise the Minister's office was the suggestion that the department had advised Mr Crean, when employment Minister, that unemployment by the year 2000 would have been at best 6.8%. We have no such advice.
Mr Grant added that there was no way such a conclusion could be drawn from the advice given to Mr Crean.

There is a pattern from Senator Vanstone of deliberately misleading the Senate and the Australian people. There is no other conclusion any reasonable person could draw but that it is a deliberate pattern of deceit on her part—on a minister's part. She simply has no understanding of her responsibilities to the parliament and to the public as the minister responsible for employment, education, training and youth affairs in this government. Minister, you ought to do the honourable thing and resign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I find Senator Faulkner's comments totally unacceptable. I wanted to touch upon that `Wright family' matter of public record—in fact, a matter of public notoriety.

SPEECH.PARA: When we went through the exercise in the estimates committee and were given the inadvertent misinformation and a press release was produced by a member who sits opposite, Senator Ferris, based upon that answer, that press release gained a great deal of publicity. In fact, many references had been made to the front page of the Daily Telegraph and the headline `Millionaires on Welfare'.

The minister was advised by her department—it was tabled and recorded in Hansard that that was erroneous and that advice was received by the minister on 26 September in a minute from the secretary to her department. I do not think that it is ordinary for the secretary to a minister's department to formally apologise for misleading, thereby giving the minister no cause for suspecting that the matter was not serious, and then making a recommendation in the minute that the minister issue a media release. With that minute was enclosed a draft media release. That was on 26 September.

The secretary to the department was under no misapprehension that it was the minister's duty to correct the misapprehension—this matter of public notoriety—that was in the public arena and to do it quickly. The way to do it quickly was to release a media release, not to write to the secretary to the department, which may well have been another duty that the minister had.

The minister said in answer to a question today that the media makes many little errors of their own making and of the making of other people who advise them and that the minister is not responsible for correcting all of those misadvices and misreportages. But the minister is responsible to correct misinformation in the media for which she is responsible. In this case, there is no doubt that the report, although based on Senator Ferris's media release, was based on the words of the minister and was so serious that her own departmental secretary had recommended to her that a media release be issued and, by implication, be issued forthwith.
The Prime Minister's A guide on key elements of ministerial responsibility says:
Ministers must be honest in their public dealings and should not intentionally mislead the Parliament or the public.
In this case the committee had been misled and also the public. It goes on:
Any misconception caused inadvertently should be corrected at the earliest opportunity.

When was the earliest opportunity? The secretary to the department was in no doubt. That was then and there. The secretary to the department recommended to the minister that a media release be issued and I suggest the implication is `then and there'. In relation to the duty of the minister that the Prime Minister's statement requires, it is clear that the minister's duty was to issue the media release and correct the misconception, which the minister says was caused inadvertently, at the earliest opportunity, not two weeks later. That is what the minister did.

We have an unintentional misconception, a breach of the Prime Minister's code and a case where the department has given the lead to the secretary to the department and the minister has chosen not to take it. I suggest that this is a case of taking political advantage out of the misconception, nothing less. The media may not always get it right, but when it is not their fault, the party at fault—in this case, it is the minister—should accept responsibility for correcting the misconception.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a proposition that calls for the Senate to note Senator Vanstone's appalling array of answers today. This is predicated on a whole series of gaffes that she has made, fundamentally geared to the issue of the quest for truth. Of course, Senator Vanstone's quest for truth may never ever be achieved. She probably never will be able to find the holy grail that she seeks. The tangled web of fake families, bogus babies, advices from the secretary covered up, injudicious statements to the Senate and dorothy dixers have snared her in her own failures to actually be able to respond. . . . DEETYA has advised that at the time of the election, on information available to the previous government, unemployment in 2000 would have been between 6.8 and 7.3 per cent.

The minister quite clearly reinforced that view in an interview on Channel 10 on 25 August and in this chamber on 10 September. Of course, the department indicated its position very quickly, after the publication of these views, in an answer to a question that was posed by the opposition. Mr Hollway indicated to us that the department had written to the office of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs to draw the attention of the office to the incorrect reporting in the Australian on 19 August 1996 which implied that the department had advised the former Labor government that a five per cent unemployment rate was unachievable.

BREAK.PARA: Dr Volker—Again, Senator, we provided a brief which outlined the assumptions which would be needed to get there.

In your view is there any way that such a conclusion could be fairly drawn from the advice given to the former minister, Mr Crean?
Mr Grant replied:

We see a similar pattern on 23 September in regard to the so-called Wright family. The minister had a big day on 23 September. She had already been down, before she arrived at the estimates committee, to an education conference at Darling Harbour in Sydney. In an address which was entitled `The quest for truth' she told a distinguished audience:

Unfortunately, this political scenario often means that the truth, the facts and the figures are lost. The headline, the grab and the spin take over from rational and informed debate. As a politician I can live with this. However, as a custodian of the nation's higher education system I am perplexed and concerned that important information about such a vital sector is distorted and ignored.
She went on to say:
The distortion of information carried to the voters distorts and damages the democratic process.

That is precisely what she has done with the Wright family. She indicated quite clearly that she has in fact misled this chamber. Some pretty important issues arise from this. It strikes me, from one of the biggest and most important government departments in this country, that such poorly constructed and consequently useless information could in fact be produced. How could that information find its way to the minister and into the Senate? The other important issue is: why did the minister take so long to correct her answer, quite clearly in breach of the ministerial guidelines that her Prime Minister has set down?

I repeat: Senator Vanstone's quest for the truth may never ever be achieved. She will probably never be able to meet the criteria and the standards set down in terms of reasonable ministerial behaviour. As a consequence, she ought perhaps now consider her position and resign. (Time expired)

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Carr interjecting—

The history of such remonstrances began in 1641 with events that are rather famous in terms of the history of our Westminster system. On that occasion in the year 1641 Charles Stuart, who subsequently became Charles I of England, caused the House of Commons to be invaded for the purpose of arresting five of its members whose actions he was unhappy with. On that occasion, the Speaker of the House of Commons delivered a remonstrance in such hard terms to the monarch that a monarch has not dared by tradition to set foot in the House of Commons ever since, except by invitation of that house.

The action is not unprecedented in respect of the Northern Territory in that the Northern Territory presented a remonstrance to the federal government in 1962, protesting then about the fact that it was not a self-governing territory and that it should have been. The reason I note that, as the Chief Minister of Northern Territory noted in the territory parliament, of which I was privileged to be a member for 10 years, is the action was in fact a landmark action that assisted in the political campaign that was being waged at the time and culminated successfully in 1978 in the granting of self-government to the Northern Territory—a self-government which I believe has been exercised responsibly in the 18 years that we have had self-government.

As you know, Madam President, I do not say that lightly because it has been the Country Liberal Party that has been in operation for the whole of those 18 years. I have a view that I have certainly expressed in the Northern Territory before, and can I say it is not a view that has been entirely welcomed by every member of my own party: that is, having spent the first 10 years of my life in the Northern Territory under the so-called delights of centralised government and actually working under a Canberra administration—having experienced that for 10 years and having experienced self-government for 10 years—I would much prefer the Northern Territory to be governed by the worst of all possible administrations in the Northern Territory, which is precisely what we have, than the best of all possible administrations in Canberra. That is strongly my view.

I disagree very strongly with this euthanasia law. I think it is bad law. I believe the process that brought it to bear is even worse, but it is a law of the Northern Territory parliament. I did want to make that point. It resulted from, again, a most unusual practice in our Westminster system—that is, a conscience vote, something which is rarely exercised in Westminster parliaments under the two‐party system around the world. It is a rare event in any parliament, but on this occasion it was a conscience vote of the parliament and, again, a conscience vote in respect of the repeal bills put before the Northern Territory parliament.

I did everything that I possibly could to bring about the repeal of that act of parliament. I, along with the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, interestingly enough, believe that it will be repealed at some time. I, along with Shane Stone, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, who is on the public record with a statement with which I agree, believe that when people find out just how obnoxious this law is in practice the bill will be repealed. But it needs to be repealed by a Northern Territory parliament, not by an act of this parliament.

It is of some interest to note—and indeed the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory noted it in the debate on this remonstrance, which has been presented to this Senate—that the previous Prime Minister of Australia did in fact receive a petition, an inquiry, from a constituent with regard to exercising the federal government's undisputed powers in respect of territories with regard to this particular legislation because the particular constituent did not like the legislation. The former Prime Minister of this country replied to that constituent in the terms that it was in fact a law of the Northern Territory, that it was in the province of the territory parliament as to whether the act remained or was repealed. Therefore, he declined to give this dreadful attack on the constitution of the Northern Territory the support that the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard), I regret to say, has given it, along with the extension of the bill to the ACT.

The original bill only applied to the Northern Territory. In an attempt, albeit well meant, to accommodate the concerns of people like me, Mr Andrews redrafted the bill and extended it to the ACT. In my view, that simply made the problem of the bill even more glaring than it was before and made it more difficult.

BREAK.PARA: I simply want to conclude on that point by saying that, as far as I am concerned, this is not a question of states rights at all. I have said publicly on a number of occasions, and I will say it in here again: if the Andrews bill were presented to the federal parliament and precluded from all the parliaments of Australia voluntary active euthanasia, that particular class of law—that is, the parliament of Australia giving a medical practitioner the legal right to kill a patient, and that is what this is; this is not right to die legislation, we have had that in the territory for many years; this particular act of the Northern Territory is in fact a right for doctors to kill—I would vote in favour of it.

So my position on this, as I am sure many senators in here would understand, is not one of states rights. If the law applied equally to the states, I would have no difficulty in seeing the vote on this matter—and it is an important vote—being a genuine vote on the question of euthanasia, but it will not be. For all those people from New South Wales, Queensland and, indeed, from all the states who are voting in this debate, it will be a vote that they can take on this issue without the slightest impact in terms of their own constituencies. Therefore, it will not and cannot by definition be a true reflection of the position of this parliament on the question of euthanasia.

The fact is this legislation applies only to the territories of Australia discriminates only against the territories of Australia. In the case of the Northern Territory, it discriminates against a parliament which has been operating without let or hindrance for 18 years. That is what I profoundly object to, as much as I object to this particular law of the Northern Territory parliament.

It was a conscience vote that brought that law about. It was not in fact a piece of legislation from the Northern Territory executive which was pushed through on the numbers. As much as I dislike it, I cannot avoid looking the facts in the face and I have to concede that, rightly or wrongly, this was the true will of the Northern Territory parliament. Members of the government, and indeed members of the executive of that government, voted both for and against the legislation. Members of my own party, the Labor Party, also voted for and against the legislation.

Therefore, as a territory senator, I believe that on my part it would be a matter of utter betrayal of the parliamentary institutions of the territory in respect of this particular matter if I voted to support a bill which amends the constitution of the Northern Territory in such a way as to preclude an entire set of laws from being passed in that parliament. The remonstrance and the letter read as follows—
THE REMONSTRANCE
The Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory with respect and humility addresses itself to
The Honourable The President and Members of the Senate; and The Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Whereas:- The Commonwealth Parliament conferred by way of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act S 978, a substantial grant of self-governing powers on the Northern Territory with its own legislature (the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory) with a plenary grant of legislative power for the peace, order and good government for the Northern Territory, with its own new body politic under the Crown with a wide grant of executive power (see Northern Territory (Self Government) Act Regulations) and with its own judicial system.
Whereas:- In 1995 the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory ~enacted the Rights of the Terminally lil Act and the Administrator assented to that Act

Whereas:- The Full Court of the Northern Territory Supreme Court held in Wake and Gondarra v Northern Territory that the Rights of the Terminally lil Act was within the legislative and executive powers of the self governing Northern Territory.

Whereas:- A Bill entitled the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 was introduced into the House of Representatives by the Honourable Member for Menzies. This Bill seeks to restrict the plenary grant of legislative power of the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory under the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978.
Whereas:- The Euthanasia Law Bill 1996 constitutes a direct attack on the self government powers of the Northern Territory.
Whereas:- The Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory is fully elected on democratic principles to represent the people of the Northern Territory and to act on their behalf.
The Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory presents its grievances to the Commonwealth Parliament.
THE GRIEVANCES

1. The Northern Territory having been granted self governing powers, the duly elected representatives of the people of the Northern Territory are aggrieved that there should be any attempt to diminish these self governing powers by the proposed enactment of the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996.
As Witness:

The Northern Territory and its residents have had a long history of seeking autonomy in control of their own affairs. However up until 1978 the Northern Territory was largely controlled by Commonwealth Ministers and public servants from Canberra.

This changed in 1978 with the passage of the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978, in which the Commonwealth Parliament publicly recorded that it was desirable by reason of the political and economic development of the Northern Territory, to confer self government on the Territory, and for that purpose to provide, among other things for the establishment of separate political, representative and administrative institutions in the Territory and to give the Territory control over its own Treasury:" (See 4th preamble to the Northern Territory (Self Government) Act

That Act created or recognised all three traditional arms of government (legislative, executive and judicial), and thereby granted the Northern Territory self government separate from the Commonwealth.

The legislative arm of this grant, the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory was given plenary powers to make laws for the peace, order and good government of the Territory (see s.6 Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978).

The High Court has since recognised that the grant of legislative power is not exercised as a mere delegate of the Commonwealth Parliament but is in fact exercised by self‐governing Territories in their own right.

The Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory is fully elected on democratic principles to represent the people of the Northern Territory and has full power and authority to make laws on matters such as voluntary euthanasia.

Whilst the Commonwealth Parliament has constitutional power to make laws for the government of the Northern Territory and the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory can't make laws that are inconsistent with laws of the Commonwealth which apply in the Northern Territory, the Commonwealth Parliament has never before sought to take away any of the legislative powers conferred upon the Northern Territory's Legislative Assembly.

It is one of the conventions of self government in the Westminster tradition that once self government is granted to a political entity, it should not thereafter be taken away except in the most extreme circumstances, for example, war or civil disturbance. See submission of the Commonwealth Attorney General's Department to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Northern Territory, page 8 of Parliamentary paper No.281 of 1974 where it also states that it would be politically unthinkable to take away such powers after they had been granted.

The Euthanasia Laws Bill as introduced in the House of Representatives seeks to directly diminish the plenary grant of legislative powers to the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory conferred by s.6 of the Northern Territory (Self Government) Act 1978.
The Bill if enacted would be in clear breach of Ule above mentioned convention and would constitute an undermining of Ule principles of self government.

2. The duly elected representatives of the people of the Northern Territory are aggrieved that the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 would, if enacted, terminate the future operation of a law already lawfully enacted by the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory.
As Witness:

The Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, if enacted, would have a dual effect. It would not only result in the diminution of the plenary legislative powers of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly as per 1 above, but it would also terminate the operation of an existing Northern Territory law lawfully enacted and assented to, namely the Rights of the Terminally lil Act 1995.

The Commonwealth Parliament has never previously enacted legislation to terminate a law of the Northern Territory lawfully enacted. The Euthanasia Laws Bill would in this respect also be in breach of the conventions of self-government.

3. The duly elected representatives of the people of the Northern Territory are aggrieved that the enactment of the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 will create uncertainty as to the operation of other existing laws of the Northern Territory.
As Witness:

The Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 proposes to diminish the legislative power of the Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory in respect of certain forms of intentional killing and the assisting of a person to terminate his or her life. It is not limited to preventing the enactment of a Rights of the Terminally lil Act
This has the capacity to create uncertainty as to the validity of a number of other existing Northern Territory laws and possible future laws. For example laws regarding criminal responsibility.
It is highly undesirable that there should be any uncertainty in respect of such laws.

4. The duly elected representatives of the people of the Northern Territory are aggrieved, given the significance of the matter, that it is proposed to enact the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 through a separate but concurrent sittings of the House of Representatives in a side chamber, rather than with full debate in the normal Parliamentary Chamber.
As Witness:

The Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 raises issues of great public importance. The most important of these is the constitutional question of whether a parliament, having once granted self governing powers to another political entity, can thereafter unilaterally take back that grant in whole or part This is a point of fundamental constitutional significance, with ramifications going well beyond the Northern Territory.

The second point of public importance is whether under existing constitutional arrangements in Australia it is appropriate for the Commonwealth Parliament to determine issues concerning voluntary euthanasia.
A third issue of public importance is the merits or otherwise of legally recognising voluntary euthanasia.

These issues of public importance are matters of considerable public interest, which the representatives of the Northern Territory consider if they are to be considered by the Commonwealth Parliament at all, should not be assigned to a side chamber of the Commonwealth Parliament.

5. The duly elected representatives of the people of the Northern Territory are aggrieved that the Commonwealth Parliament, in debating the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, Is proposing to enact legislation for self governing Territories that constitutionally it could not enact for existing States.
As Witness:
Under s.51 of the Australian Constitution the Commonwealth Parliament has no legislative power in respect of the subject matter of voluntary euthanasia. This is a `state type' matter.

Since the grant of self-government to the Northern Territory in—1978 the Commonwealth Parliament as a general rule has not sought to legislate for the Northern Territory in `state type' matters except in respect of specific reserve powers. (See Regulation 4(2) under the Northern Territory (Self-Government) Act 1978.) The subject of voluntary euthanasia is not such a reserved power.

The Commonwealth Parliament has no power to either diminish the legislative power of a State parliament or to terminate a State law. The only power of the Commonwealth Parliament is to enact laws on matters for which it has Federal responsibility under S.51 of the Constitution. Such laws would override a State law under S.109 of the Constitution to the extent of any inconsistency.

6. The duly elected representatives of the people of the Northern Territory are aggrieved that the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996 would, if enacted, be inconsistent with the undertakings that have already been given for a grant of Statehood for the Northern Territory.
As Witness:
The Northern Territory is progressing along a path of constitutional development.

The grant of self-government was an important step in that process but does not amount to a grant of Statehood. With a view to facilitating the future grant of Statehood, the Commonwealth already treats the Northern Territory as far as possible as if it were a State, for example, for financial purposes through the Grants Commission process and the Loans Council.
The proposal for a grant of Statehood now has general support from most Australian governments including te Commonwealth, although no time lines have yet been fixed.

To now enact the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, being a Bill that deals with `state type' matters under the Constitution, would be to act contrary to the general progression towards Statehood and create future impediments to such a grant.

Constitutionally the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996, if enacted, could only operate in the Northern Territory up until the grant of Statehood but not beyond that date (subject to the terms and conditions under s.121 of the Constitution, although there are strong arguments that such terms and conditions could not be used to support the validity of the Euthanasia Laws Bill after a grant of Statehood). On this basis the Euthanasia Laws Bill if enacted would only be of transitional effect.

Given such a limited effect, the duly elected representatives of the Northern Territory are aggrieved that the Commonwealth Parliament should be used in this ad hoc fashion to undermine the principles of self government and to create impediments to the future constitutional development of the Northern Territory.
The Prayer:

The Legislative Assembly of the Northern Territory humbly prays that the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia give consideration to the grievances herein set out and seek means to alleviate the distress of the people of the Northern Territory by not proceeding further with the Euthanasia Laws Bill 1996.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
