Those who know Broken Hill will appreciate that the dumps and tailings stand very high as a permanent reminder that mining is a dangerous occupation, but having a monument that will stand out and be visible for many miles around will, of course, be an ever present reminder to the people there that this is a dangerous occupation. It will be an ever present reminder to anybody visiting the area that mining is a very dangerous occupation. The monument will also ensure that, for those people who go there, industrial occupational health and safety issues will always be of the utmost significance.

To those people who were involved in the memorial service and to those families which have lost loved ones on the Line of Lode, I extend my condolences and thoughts. I really did appreciate that memorial service. I appreciated the fact that the unveiling of the plans for the memorial was conducted by the grand daughter of someone who lost their life on the Line of Lode and by someone who had been involved with the University of South Australia School of Architecture in designing the memorial. To all those involved, I wish you well. I found it a very moving tribute. I found the camaraderie and the friendship that existed in that community—in spite of the tribulations and the trials that they have had to live through—very rewarding as well. I wish them all the best.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —In the past I have risen to honour the memory of many of Australia's finest economists, the last one being a highly respected statistician. Tonight I would like to spend a moment of the Senate's time reflecting on the extraordinary life of Sir Roland Wilson—arguably Australia's finest statistician—who, sadly, at a great age, passed away last Thursday.

SPEECH.PARA: Roland Wilson will long be remembered as one who made an exceptional contribution to Australia in the field of applied economics. He was a man of remarkable intellect and independence of thought, who was never afraid to speak his mind. These attributes sometimes brought him into conflict with his peers and colleagues, but they also brought innumerable benefits to the field of economics here in Australia.

It gives me great pleasure to highlight the fact that such a distinguished economist was born and bred in my home state of Tasmania. In fact, he was born in Ulverstone, a beautiful little town of some 11,000 people on the central north‐west coast. After being educated at Devonport High School, Sir Roland gained his first degree—Bachelor of Commerce—at the University of Tasmania. He eventually returned to the University of Tasmania to lecture in economics after undertaking studies at Oxford University as Tasmania's Rhodes scholar. May I add that Sir Roland Wilson was actually the first boy from a Tasmanian government high school to win such an award.

Later as a Commonwealth Fund Fellow he completed his PhD at the University of Chicago. As the Canberra Times reported yesterday, it was the entry into the Public Service which caused considerable friction on one occasion because he was recruited as a professional statistician at a time when doctors and lawyers were the only graduates in the Public Service. Bringing a new academic discipline to the job, his new colleagues at the statistician's office were incensed at the threat his appointment posed to their job security. Remembering this was in 1932, during the depths of the depression, those in the statistician's office were very much afraid that their jobs were on the line. People usually started at the bottom of the ladder as an inkwell filler or messenger boy, not as a Doctor of Philosophy in Economics. They decided to go on strike for a day to make their point. However, to their honour, it was these same colleagues who, four years later, were the first to congratulate him when he was appointed Commonwealth Statistician and Economic Adviser to the Treasury, the youngest man ever to hold that position. They now endorsed him as the best person for that position.

BREAK.PARA: Once Australia became involved in World War II, he was appointed to establish the Department of Labour and National Service and he became its head. Following the war, he served the United Nations as Chairman of the Economic and Employment Commission. This appointment came just four years after the establishment of the United Nations in 1945. It is interesting to note in passing that his death occurred on the day observed by all around the world as United Nations day.

As a consequence of these appointments, his time as Australia's Chief Statistician was fragmented. Finally, in 1951 he was appointed Secretary to the Treasury, a position he held until his retirement in 1966. This was not the end of his career, as he served both the Commonwealth Banking Corporation and Qantas as chairman until the mid‐1970s. This distinguished Australian provided a model for all public servants in his unstinting and selfless commitment to the good government of our country. Even in his retirement, although never one to mince words, he refused to speak out publicly on economic policy and practice.

In 1989 the Distinguished Fellow Award was conferred on him by the Economic Society of Australia for his exceptional contribution to Australia. I am sure there will be many who would wish to emulate him as an outstanding Australian public figure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to again raise the question of John Bevins Pty Ltd and remarks made in this Senate some weeks ago. I thought I would read onto the record the correspondence on this particular matter which involves both John Bevins, Ian McDonald and Senator O'Chee and let the record speak for itself. The circumstances were Senator O'Chee made some allegations in this chamber which prompted this correspondence. The first letter is from Mr John Bevins, Executive Chairman of John Bevins Pty Ltd, and it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator,

I am deeply concerned that you claimed, in the Senate tonight, that my agency had offered a lucrative contract to a public servant employed in the Commonwealth Government's Office of Government Information and Advertising (OGIA). The clear implication of your comments was that this was an improper inducement—intended to affect the impartiality of a public servant charged with the responsibility of independently assessing tender documents submitted for the National Gun Control Public Education Campaign.
Your claim is entirely false. Check the facts, you will find this to be so.

I would like to believe that you inadvertently misled parliament. If you are an honourable man, then you will correct the record and apologise for the damage that you have done to our reputation and that of the public servant who has been drawn into this matter.

If, on the other hand, you wish to maintain your current position and leave this falsehood uncorrected, then I challenge you to repeat the defamatory statements without the protection of parliamentary privilege.
Then in a further letter to Senator O'Chee of 17 October, Ian McDonald, an employee of John Bevins, said:
Senator,

A week ago my partner, John Bevins, wrote to inform you that statements which you made in the Senate last Thursday evening relating to our agency had no basis in fact. Separately, you have since received from Mr Simon Longstaff a copy of his Statutory Declaration in which he states his belief that your assertion was `without foundation' as was the `imputation that any of the parties acted improperly'.
In his letter, John asked that you check the facts and correct the record.
To this point we are not aware of any action which you have taken to do either. Nor have we had the courtesy of a reply.
Accompanying this note is the fax header sheet of—
Ms X's—
C.V (which she sent to me last month at my request).
I use the name `Ms X' because I do not want to reveal the name of the public servant at this stage. The letter continues:

You will note that it is dated and fax date‐stamped 17 September—a week after the DDB appointment was announced. For your assertion of a `lucrative position' being offered to hold true, one would then have to accept that:
i. we offered her a position several weeks before the `Guns Amnesty' agency decision date and then got around to asking for her C.V. a week after it
and/or
ii. we asked for and received her C.V. several weeks after—according to your theory—we had already offered her a job.
Accepting that a C.V. is normally a critical input to any executive appointment, perhaps you will detect something not quite right with each of those?
For the record, the agency has never offered—
Ms X—

any `position', any `contract', any consultancy, or anything otherwise. We have the very highest regard for her professional abilities and for her exemplary personal conduct, but that is nonetheless so.

John wrote that, if you are an honourable man, you will correct the record. May I add that if in the face of all indications to the contrary you still believe that we have acted improperly, then if you possess the courage of your beliefs you'll repeat them outside parliament. Either course would provide us with something to respect.
Senator O'Chee responded on 18 October in the following terms:
Dear Mr McDonald,
I refer to your letter and that of your colleague Mr Bevins.

I note your protestations, and had been intending to make a statement on the adjournment this week, however before I could do so Senator Ray spoke on the matter on Monday night. I can only assume this contribution was based on material you had provided him.

My intention had been to state to the Senate your disagreement with my speech last week. Since you chose an adversarial and alternative route to achieve your objectives I considered myself relieved of any ethical obligation I had previously felt towards you.

Finally, I have no intention of taking up your puerile and trite suggestion that I set myself up for a defamation action. I am already involved in two such cases because I have had the integrity to stand up for my constituents (where, of course, truth is no defence) and I do not feel compelled to needlessly involve myself in another to oblige someone whose interest is purely self.
Yours sincerely,
Bill O'Chee.
The final piece of correspondence comes from Mr Ian McDonald. He says:

BREAK.PARA: Senator,
May I acknowledge my receipt this morning of your 18 October letter.
Its content was much as I had expected it might be but I must admit to some surprise at three comments which you've made within it:

1. That we chose "an adversarial and alternative route": Seriously! What would you expect us to do when we had been defamed in a most cowardly manner yet could gain no response, let alone satisfaction, from yourself? Clearly our initial choice was to attempt to resolve the situation with yourself—but to no effect.
2. That you've found that "truth is no defence": In the context of anything which you've uttered in The Senate on this issue, where does "truth" enter into this?

3. That you would not "oblige someone whose interest is purely self": In that an individual's reputation is about as "self" as you can get, I agree with you as to our motivation. But I can't follow the logic which allows you to believe that our defence of our reputations means you can absolve yourself of any "ethical obligation" to either correct your untruth or to otherwise test its validity?

Parliamentary privilege is both a necessary and a wonderful thing. It can achieve much in the hands of honourable and conscientious parliamentarians who understand that the power and freedom which it grants to them comes at the cost of an absolute obligation to use it honestly.
But Bill, I'm sure that you don't need me to tell you that! Only you can truly say whether you've met that brief in this instance. We can do no more than hold an opinion.

I did not really enter the chamber tonight to tackle Senator O'Chee. But in a previous adjournment speech I wondered how this internal information out of DAS got into the hands of Senator O'Chee. So I pursued this matter at the estimates committee. I asked the Secretary to the Department of Administrative Services how this knowledge got out. I went on to say:
There was no contact with Minister Jull's office on this subject to your knowledge?
I was answered:
Contact with Mr Jull's office in relation to what, Senator?
I said:
Potential conflict of interest by an OGIA officer?
He said he would have to defer to Ms Moore, the Assistant Manager. But he did confirm:
At one stage a query was raised from the minister's office about those intentions.
I then asked Ms Moore:
Was that in writing or by way of phone?
Ms Moore said:
I had a phone call.
I asked:
From whom?
Ms Moore replied:
From Miss Farnsworth—
Mr Jull's media adviser—
asking me if I heard these rumours or discussions and if I could clarify them.
I asked:
What did you respond?
Ms Moore said:
I clarified them along the lines that the secretary has said.
So I put to Ms Moore that she not only clarified them but she also told Minister Jull's office that the officer concerned had declared a potential conflict of interest. She says, `Yes, Senator.'

So what appears to have happened is this: rumours circulate that there was a potential conflict of interest in OGIA, the minister's office rings and gets those confirmed and then apparently briefs a senator or senators in the coalition who come into this parliament and dump on this particular officer. Who speaks for that officer is the question I ask? As ministers, your first requirement is to defend your department and the officers in the department. It is not to have them slandered in this particular chamber. Your job as a minister and Minister Jull's job is to defend his own.

If it is ever proved that Minister Jull's office initiated these defamatory statements in the Senate, he should give the game away. It would be one of the greatest betrayals by a minister I have ever seen if that is the case. I ask Mr Jull here in this chamber to deny whether his office passed the information on to Senator O'Chee.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 20 September 1996:

(1) To what extent is it truly owner driven and to what extent is it price driven.
(2) Is an owner given any real choice as to what goes into his or her house.
(3)(a) How is the department going about giving the owners a choice; and (b) are owners being given any option, other than in aesthetic areas such as what style of windows to have.

(4)(a) How many owners of the 240 houses insulated to date have been given the option of, or even told that there is an option of, wool batts in their ceilings; and (b) are owners encouraged to take polyester or other insulation because it is half the price.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The residential insulation scheme carried out by the Sydney Aircraft Noise Insulation Project (SANIP) is owner driven to the extent that:

PARA.TAB: the owner elects to participate in the scheme at the time of invitation by the Project
the owner authorises the preparation by the Project of a scope of works for his/her home
the owner chooses the type of windows and the type of soft fibre insulation to be used
the owner chooses three builders from the accredited panel to quote the work
the owner chooses the builder he or she wishes to undertake the work following quotations
the owner manages the builder on a day‐to‐day basis (with the SANIP staff providing support)
the owner signs a certificate of completion at the end of the job and the Project inspects the work to ensure that it has been completed in accordance with the scope of work.

ANSWER.PARA: The scheme is price driven to the extent that:

PARA.TAB: builders compete for the work;
some quotes are negotiated where they are outside the Project estimate by more than 10%; and
the Government has established a $45,000 upper limit on assistance.

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Homeowners may choose:

PARA.TAB: fully ducted airconditioning or a mechanical ventilation system;
from a range of different window types;

ANSWER.PARA: from a variety of soft fibre ceiling insulation materials;

PARA.TAB: from two types of lining used in ventilation ductwork.

ANSWER.PARA: (3)(a) Information pamphlets sent to each householder set out the areas where `owners choice' exists. This choice is reinforced in briefing sessions for homeowners and set out in more detail in the Homeowner Manual provided at briefings on the scheme. Current arrangements are that homeowners are given product description sheets for approved products which also contain contact details for manufacturers and display centre locations. The homeowner is requested to choose between alternative products prior to the visit to the home by the Project's technical staff at which the scope of works setting out insulation treatments is prepared.
(b) See answer to Part (2).

(4)(a) All homeowners have been advised of the availability of wool insulation since it was first approved for use in the scheme in November 1995. There are currently six suppliers of accredited wool insulation products.
(b) No. At present wool insulation is slightly cheaper than polyester.
